body: Merged, thanks!
Done. MIT licensed.

Small issue with this: **instanceof** _window.File_ works when the file was uploaded directly, but not necessarily in other contexts. I'm trying to use this library in an offline Chome app, in which case the _File_ object (actually a _FileEntry_ object) comes from a different window or iframe and will never match _window.File_.

Possible solutions I've found are checking _img.constructor.name_ or _(new Object).toString.call(img)_. Any better ideas?
bug reflected in new pull request
I got this problem too. Anyone know how to fix?
this code makes exif-js work for me in chrome. can we get it pulled into exif-js?
big thx for this fix, now it works for me in chrome/opera(webkit)

Exif.js no longer uses binaryajax.js. Is this still a problem?

Yes, it does look like there's an issue there. The file seems to load fine in Photoshop so I assume it's a problem in exif.js - but I haven't found the cause yet. The way I'm reading ExifIFDPointer seems to put it a few bytes off from where it should be (in this file).
Looks like this has been covered by https://github.com/jseidelin/exif-js/pull/6

Reading the 2.3 spec regarding the value immediately following the 0x002A magic number:

> Usually the first IFD starts immediately next to TIFF header, so this offset has value '0x00000008'.

I would interpret "usually" as meaning "but not always" (leaning in favor of reading and using that offset value instead of requiring it to be 8).

---

Also, perl's [Image-MetaData-JPEG library](http://cpansearch.perl.org/src/RJBS/Image-MetaData-JPEG-0.156/lib/Image/MetaData/JPEG/parsers/app1_exif.pl) handles it like this:

``` perl
    # decode the offset of the 0th IFD: this is usually 8, but we are
    # not going to assume it. Do not store the record (it is uninteresting)
    my $ifd0_link = $this->read_record($LONG, $offset); 
```
@jseidelin Could you provide a feedback on that PR ?
Looks good, merging. Thanks!

Yeah, the format of the makernote data is vendor-specific (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exchangeable_image_file_format#MakerNote_data) so you need to know which camera took the picture in order to properly parse the data.

Currently I'm checking by regex, but it's seems really unefficient.

This problem is about CORS policy in images. 
You can read more about this here:
http://blog.codepen.io/2013/10/08/cross-domain-images-tainted-canvas/
And read more about `crossorigin` img attribute:
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/CORS_settings_attributes
Draw the image to a canvas and present that for download: https://github.com/codepo8/image-data-cleaner/blob/c732dc05ff4cc8946301e0b9cd30c8c5a33815c6/scripts/cleaner.js#L56-L59
you can use promise to synchronize it.

Thanks @martinkunkel, though wouldn't the value be "1/1000" rather than "1/1000s".

The exif spec says that exposure time should be a rational, rather than a string.

doesn't that apply to the way the exif data is stored in the jpg rather than the output format? i agree, "1/1000" is probably better. it's still a string though.

Hi, I was wondering what's the point behind your request, to enhance performance?

If so, i think it should be pretty fast already, for example i use exif.js to deal with RAW photos, and to process ~40MB of data it takes a few milliseconds.

I.e:

```
19:36:39.896 exif: timer started index.js:109
19:36:39.897 Got file of length 37835264 exif.js:386:20
19:36:39.900 exif: 3.92ms index.js:118
19:36:39.900 EXIF Object { Compression: 6, ImageDescription: "SONY DSC", Make: "SONY ", Model: "DSLR-A900", Orientation: 1, XResolution: 350, YResolution: 350, ResolutionUnit: 2, Software: "DSLR-A900 v1.00", DateTime: "2008:12:22 16:37:58", 30 more… } 1 index.js:121:4
```

(Firefox 41 on a core i7 laptop)

Hence, i'm against such change unless it's provided through an opt-in option :-)

fwiw, i get correct _Orientation_ values for these images (3 and 8, respectively)

I.e:

```
19:55:43.625 exif: timer started index.js:109
19:55:43.625 Got file of length 3943134 exif.js:386:20
19:55:43.625 225 exif.js:415:24
19:55:43.625 Found 0xFFE1 marker exif.js:421:28
19:55:43.626 Unknown tag: 0xc4a5 exif.js:558:1
19:55:43.627 exif: 2.48ms index.js:118
19:55:43.627 EXIF Object { ImageDescription: "Exif_JPEG_PICTURE                  …", Make: "RICOH      ", Model: "G700 SE        ", Orientation: 8, XResolution: 72, YResolution: 72, ResolutionUnit: 2, Software: "G700SE Firmware", DateTime: "2013:06:13 14:33:48", YCbCrPositioning: 2, 56 more… } 8
```

Perhaps you're using an older exif.js, dunno.

> Is is somehow possible to read exif data synchronously?

Yes, deal with the `<img/>`s data yourself and then call `EXIF.readFromBinaryFile()`

You are totally correct, I thought the size of the files was slowing down my project, and this was the only solution. After more investigation, exif-js is not slow at all. Thanks for the good response.
Try using NATIVE_URI for your destination value.

You get the values as degrees, minutes, seconds. This is how they are stored in the file, and what you want is decimal degrees, so you will have to make some calculations to convert them. 
Pseudocode:
decDegrees = GPSLattitude[0] + (GPSLattitude[1]/60) + (GPSLattitude[2]/(60*60))

I find instructions two days after starting, and the read from binary section suggests I go over to Mozilla. I don't doubt that your script can do all I need it too. You've already put in the hard work to get it where it is, an updated demo example with all the various uses would go a long way to increase the user benefit of your software.

I solved this issue by removing the img tag and adding a new one, this allows you to use browser caching while still forcing this library to reload.

I merged. 
Had some small doubts, like shouldn't you put this in the definitelytyped repo instead? But it's been a while since I used Typescript. And it seems now 'typings' is the thing to use. Does this conform to their way of working? Shouldn't there be a typings folder or typings.json or something?

Hey @bartvanderwal, yes sorry I should have looked closer at this commit. Indeed the file should either be called index.d.ts _or_ there should be a "types" or "typings" property in the package.json that points to the .d.ts file.

A consumer should not have to use `/// <reference>` to access a module's types when using the above method, simply requiring the module should be enough.

More on [publishing typings](https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/declaration-files/publishing.html).

To add a bit more detail here, [operator precedence](https://developer.mozilla.org/en/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Operators/Operator_Precedence) is the problem:

`&&` evaluate before `||` so, if the left side of `||` is `true`, the result will always be `true` (the right side is still evaluated first).

Right test is:
```javascript
(self.Image && img instanceof self.Image || self.HTMLImageElement && img instanceof self.HTMLImageElement) && !img.complete
```
You can make it more straightforward to read by adding a couple of parenthesis (as does this pull request):
```javascript
((self.Image && img instanceof self.Image) || (self.HTMLImageElement && img instanceof self.HTMLImageElement)) && !img.complete
```

Nice suggestion. I've been looking for ways to beat Chrome's aggressive caching when using exif.js as well. 

Two problems though:
1. If you're going to add parameters to the end of the src string from S3 it already has a ton of params added so your code would need to add "&cb="+new Date().getTime(). This also leads to the question, what if you're not loading images from S3? You need to be able to detect if this is the first param or the last param in the image src. Not impossible, just thought I should point that out.

2. This won't work for S3 Images. If you add a parameter to the end of the src string it returns 403 Forbidden.

I was just able to fix my issue with caching images and not being able to retrieve the EXIF data. Rather than salting the image URL with a timestamp I am able to disable the cache on the request to the img.src in the getImageData function. 

Try this:

`...`
`http.open("GET", img.src, true);`
`http.responseType = "arraybuffer";`
`http.setRequestHeader("Cache-Control", "no-cache") // Add this line`
`http.send(null);`
`...`


This will prevent Chrome from using the cached version of the image asset when performing the request and force the request to send the CORS headers again.
use the `2.1.0` can resolve this problem.

@peterlitvak's code worked for me - thank you. I tried using the cache-control as an alternative but this seemed to cause a problem with it working on Firefox. The timestamp worked with Chrome, Safari and Firefox.

I agree, exploring this library was offputting but it works so well. So much hard work has gone into this project and it works so well but I fear people will not use it or contribute because of the high barrier to entry.

I would be happy to help out simplifying the code base. 

A starting point would be to write some tests for some of the lower level functionality to ensure people can contribute without breaking core functionality. I propose [Ava.js](https://github.com/avajs/ava.) as a test library. It's lightweight and very fast.

Do any of the project's contributors to weight in?

I guess this project is a bit on the backburner, so my suggestion is to push forward:
- fork the project
- make changes to the API until you feel something is coming along nicely

If the PR just ends up rotting without progress, just publish an NPM artifact under your own NPM namespace `npm install @thomasankorn/exif-js` as a reasonable compromise.

EXIF-information is stored in the picture at creation time (but can be added through other editing programs as well, after the fact). There is no EXIF tag that will show you where an image was stored. That would make no sense: that would mean all handling software would need to update this information every time the picture was moved from one storage medium to the next.

So no, you cannot use exif.js to know whether the image was directly captured by the camera or was already existing. You can use other ways though, but they have nothing to do with EXIF:
1. Restrict the file input to image types and set the `capture` attribute to `camera`. That will force phones to open the native camera. See [this link](https://coderwall.com/p/epwmoa/html5-mobile-device-camera-access) for more info.
2. Supply an alternative input method for normal files.

This is only supported by mobile os'es, btw. If you have any other questions regarding this, please open a new question on Stack Overflow. You should close this one, as it is not related to EXIF.JS.

I have finally managed to solve my problem of reading the exif data from an image and solving the problem of cross browser access..
I found a script for handling cross browser requests in IIS (http://gkb.wikidot.com/setting-cors-on-iis-8) to be placed in the web.config file in the web directory where my Javascript resides.
The script comprises 9 lines : 
<system.webServer>
  <httpProtocol>
    <customHeaders>
      <add name="Access-Control-Allow-Origin" value="*" />
      <add name="Access-Control-Allow-Headers" value="Content-Type" />
      <add name="Access-Control-Allow-Methods" value="GET, POST, PUT, DELETE, OPTIONS" />
    </customHeaders>
  </httpProtocol>
</system.webServer>

After running my program as http://localhost/index.html it works perfectly.

@mmase This happens when you use [strict mode](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Strict_mode). It's been there since JS v5 (2009, thanks to Douglas Crockford :)). In strict mode you can not tnot declare a new variable without an explicit `var`. Probably some other bit of JavaScript has a `"use strict";` in it, and then you use exif.

Plenty of other people have complained about this. But there are some other `for` loops that also don't have `var` yet. But I'll check the pull request.

I'm not sure this is a thing because I see a similar 10/2000 on other EXIF systems. I was able to apply a workaround right before displaying the code (outside of the EXIF library) to update the displayed number if it was showing a 10 numerator.

This is because exif-js attaches an `exifdata` property to the Image element on first execution. When `getData` is called with the same Image element, it checks if the `exifdata` property is present and reuses that instead of reprocessing the image, even if the image source has changed. See [here](https://github.com/exif-js/exif-js/blob/28f43da9b029b486c7d6b7ced373510d1f6ca357/exif.js#L982).

One way to work around this is to clear the `exifdata` property before calling `getData`: 
`delete img.exifdata`

It would probably be a good idea to add a parameter to `getData` that prevents the caching behavior.

See #163 an #143

The current workaround is to clear the `exifdata` property on the Image element before calling `getData`.

Please give details of the typescript error you get, on which line, and a relevant typescript version number.

To react to your subject: `can't find .d.ts file`, there is indeed a `exif.d.ts` file in this package as you state yourself in your first sentence. So that's a contradiction in your issue.

As to your comment about a missing `typings` property in the package.json, the package.json has a `types` field, which is a synonym/alternative to the `typings` field according to the [TypeScript manual](https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/declaration-files/publishing.html):
"Note that the "typings" field is synonymous with "types", and could be used as well."

Do you have a reason to change this? If that change solves it for you locally I'd be happy to accept a pull request.

A true issue is that there is no exif-js in the @types npm organization, but also there is no direct exif-js.ts source file as the TS manual then recommends when using `types` or `typings` property and a separate (source) .d.ts file (see above link). The type information could be siginificantly improved for better intellisense/type checking. But sadly I don't have time to work in this, but pull requests for this are also welcome.

There is indeed a problem here. The only thing necessary to demonstrate it is

    $ cd test && npm init
    $ npm install exif-js
    $ grep types node_modules/exif-js/package.json

and we see that the package.json does not include the `types` field, which means that TypeScript has no idea where to find the types file (which is there, named `exif-js.d.ts`).

I suspect that the problem is that the github repo has not been re-published to npm since the `types` field was added to `package.json`. npm reports that the package was published in September 2017 (see https://www.npmjs.com/package/exif-js), whereas the addition of `types` to `package.json` happened in February 2018. 

The error, for what it's worth, would appear on a line such as

    import * as EXIF from "exif-js";

and would read

```
Could not find a declaration file for module 'exif-js'. '/home/rtm/repos/nims/jsutils/node_modules/exif-js/exif.js' implicitly has an 'any' type.
  Try `npm install @types/exif-js` if it exists or add a new declaration (.d.ts) file containing `declare module 'exif-js';` [7016]
```

but that error is not especially surprising or useful, because we already knew that TS would not be able to find a types file if there is no `types` field in package.json, since the version of package.json which included it was apparently never published to npm.

A possible work-around is to import the package directly from github for the time being (`"exif-js": "exif-js/exif-js"`).
